content: If there are no objections, I'd like to add cover art to this puzzle.

Interesting puzzle, thanks!
One thought: It would be much harder, if he has the magic to "change" N parts of the map in order to reduce the distance.

> "index of the map with the shortest path."
I don't think its uniqueness is mentioned anywhere in the statement.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks like a fun problem to solve

I was about to approve, but Scala and OCaml base code doesn't work.

One little thing thought : what's the purpose of '.' ? can't they be walls ?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great idea and good storyline (I hope you'll put yours instead of mine)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice addition of multiple iterations. It is a little bit bland, it won't change much but maybe you would consider letting the map sizes and starting positions be different for each map? Also, not quite the same puzzle but maybe consider giving a map (consisting of ".", "#", & "T") and then having the different iterations be a set of instructions? Additionally you can add extraneous arrows so that it would force people to count the path length rather than the number of arrows as you suggested. I fear that this would only confuse entry level coders the way you suggest that you can count the number of arrows on that map as it is much easier to count while verifying that the path exists. Overall good job making a relatively unique puzzle.

Great idea!

I think you should add a bit of story as an introduction.
Something like that :
"A shady old man gave you a bunch of treasure maps of the closest dungeon. As you look at them closely, you notice they all point to the same treasure but with different paths. You have to decide which map to trust in order to be efficient in the dungeon : you never now what might lie in the shadows."

Phrase it how you like it ,but it will add a nice touch.

Is there an implicit requirement that "T" be in the same position in all of the maps? If not, I'd add tests for Treasures in different positions, just to avoid users from calculating Manhattan distances all of the time.

Side: Walls and empty squares are effectively the same. I suppose the 2 symbols are here to add a bit of confusion for the users?
I think you can remove this "S - The starting square" as you are giving start row and col.

Good point for different positions of T, I'll add several more tests.

Yeap you got that right, walls and empty squares are just for confusion.

Done :)

My version is:

"Your adventure path led you to an inn in a small, forgotten town somewhere to the North of Golem Hills
After gulping the last drop from the 9th mug of elf wine a shady old man materializes out of nowhere, in-front of you.
You start to doubt the wine.
The old man(throwing a pack of old maps on the table): Do you want to earn some good coins?
You(without looking at him): I've enough for food and wine!
The old man: What about a whole inn...!
You: Hm...
The old man: Yeees and you'll get the glory of being the first one to get to this treasure!
You(looking at the bunch of maps): But they look the same!?
The old man: Or do they, you must choose wisely.
The voice of the old man(from nowhere): Ah right, one more thing, beware of the Dragons!
You grab you staff and sword, swallow one more whole mug of wine:
Well it's glory time!"

But it is quite long, I think.

I think I've fixed the Scala base code, but I'm not sure for OCaml.

You got that right, it's for little bit of a confusion, they are basically the same.
